Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Evolution of High-latitude Permo-Triassic Paleoenvironments and their Vertebrate Communities.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Around 252 million years ago, a major mass extinction wiped out upwards of 90% of species on Earth. Coincident with this extinction, the Antarctic portion of the supercontinent of Pangea transitioned to a warmer climatic regime and became devoid of glaciers. Little is known about the survivors of the extinction in Antarctica, although it has been hypothesized that the continent?s more polar location shielded it from the worst of the extinction?s effects. The Shackleton Glacier region is the best place to study this extinction in Antarctica because it exposes the correct age rocks in abundance and relevant fossils were found there in the 1960s and 1980s. For this research, paleontologists will study fossil vertebrates that span from about 260?240 million years ago to understand how life evolved at high latitudes in the face of massive climate change. In addition, geologists will use fossil soils and fossil plant matter to more precisely understand the climate of Antarctica across this extinction boundary. These data will allow for a more complete understanding of ancient climates and how Antarctic life compared to that at lower latitudes. Undergraduate and graduate students will be actively involved in this research. Public engagement in Antarctic science will be accomplished at several natural history museums.

This three-year project will examine the evolution of Permo-Triassic paleoenvironments and their vertebrate communities by conducting fieldwork in the Shackleton Glacier region of Antarctica. The team will characterize the Permo-Triassic boundary within Shackleton area strata and correlate it to other stratigraphic successions in the region (e.g. via stable carbon isotope stratigraphy of fossilized plant organic matter). The researchers will use multiple types of data to assess the paleoenvironment, including: 1) paleosol morphology; 2) paleosol geochemistry; 3) pedogenic organic matter; and 4) fossil wood chronology and stable isotopes. The Fremouw Formation of Antarctica preserves the highest paleolatitude (~70Â° S) tetrapod fauna of the entire Triassic and thus has the potential to shed important light on the evolution of polar life during the early Mesozoic. The biology of Triassic vertebrates from Antarctica will be compared to conspecifics from lower paleolatitudes through analysis of growth in bone and tusk histology. An interdisciplinary approach will be used to address relationships between environmental change, faunal composition, and biogeographic patterns in the context of the high-latitude strata preserved in the Buckley and Fremouw formations in the Shackleton Glacier region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Important outcomes such as presentations, publications and abstracts may be accessed through the following link:

https://www.usap-dc.org/view/project/p0010213

This project is focused upon life and environments of late Permian-Triassic landscapes preserved in the upper Permian and Triassic rocks of the Transantarctic Mountain Range. The staging area for this field work was located at a temporary camp located upon Shackleton glacier, and field work was facilitated by daily helicopter transport to different outcroppings of Permian-Triassic strata within ~60 miles of the base camp.  

 

Over the course of fieldwork there were nine separate stratigraphic successions which span the Permian-Triassic boundary. The total thickness of strata which were measured, described and collected for subsequent analyses exceeds 2000 meters, paleosols, or fossilized soils included in the strata, record a change from poorly drained fluvial landscapes with stout trees including extensive woody root systems and in-situ accumulations of vascular plant organic matter in latest Permian landscapes to better drained soils with shrubby-type plants (perhaps similar to Heather) with shallow and bifurcating root systems with common vertebrate burrows which extend diagonally and downward from paleosol surfaces to 45-60 cm depth. This transition in paleosol structure and organization is interpreted to represent a substantial environmental transition from something like the McKenzie Delta during late Permian time, to something like lowland tundra dominated by shrubs and sedges with cryoturbation features. 

 

Nearly 200 samples of paleosol matrix, sedimentary rock and petrified logs were collected and shipped to Southern Methodist University for preparation as petrographic thin sections, X-ray diffraction mineral analysis, and stable isotope analysis. Petrographic analysis of paleosol matrix samples show that chemical weathering was not extensive, with feldspars and more labile minerals being present in profiles, although these labile minerals are less abundant toward to top of profiles in the Triassic strata, suggesting that chemical weathering, albeit limited, was an important part of landscape development. However, X-ray diffraction analysis of the clay-sized particles in these same samples are dominated by chlorite and illite, two minerals which are typical of cold and dry environments with limited chemical weathering, but also could be products of diagenetic alteration of pre-existing, more weathered materials. Preliminary K-Ar radioisotope analyses from these clay-sized fractions indicate an apparent age for these Permian and Triassic paleosol profiles of ~200 million years. While these age-dates are by no means final in analysis, it is significant that these preliminary age-dates are younger than depositional ages of these strata, and appear to be close to the timing of Jurassic-age extensional events and intrusive igneous events which no doubt had a significant impact on the burial conditions and diagenetic alteration of the pre-Jurassic age strata. 

 

Finally, incremental dehydration-combustion experiments were conducted on bulk coal and fossil tree petrifications in order to evaluate the stable carbon and hydrogen isotope compositions of the fossilized organic matter. The carbon isotope data is typical of C3 plants which have been reported from similar coal-forming environments in Gondwanaland. Hydrogen isotope compositions of bulk organic matter from the Permian-age coals of the Transantarctic Mountain Range are among the most negative values reported thus far, and the population of hydrogen isotope values is the most negative of any dataset collected thus far. Considering the hydrogen isotope composition of organic matter is initially affected by the stable hydrogen isotope composition of rainfall and soil water at the time of organic matter formation, these data offer insights into nature of the hydrological cycle and meteoric water line of oxygen and hydrogen isotopes in particular. That these are the most negative values reported yet suggests organic matter was derived from the most negative meteoric water stable isotope values. This is consistent with these Antarctic samples forming among the coldest of paleolandscapes compared to other coal-forming environmnents in Gondwanaland. In the coming year or so, we plan to complete this component of stable isotope analyses with serial-sampling the carbon and hydrogen isotope values of organic matter occluded with the fossil tree-ring growth series of Permian and Triassic-age fossil trees.
